section-block.rac_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Taro Gomi
section-block.rac_book_summary: This informational text introduces children to many of the exciting places numbers are found in our everyday lives. There are opportunities to spot numbers everywhere, from the grocery store to the soccer field.

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64264-3. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. I Know Numbers! by Taro Gomi. Copyright © 1985 by Taro Gomi. Translation copyright © 2017 by Chronicle Books LLC. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Chronicle Books LLC. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: ME and YOU | WEEK 1: All About Me

section-block.rac_body-text: Welcome children and tell them that you will read books, play games, and learn about numbers, shapes, and more as a class. Play a game to introduce children to each other.
Show children Number Cards 1–10. Ask children to repeat each number after you as you show the numeral on each card. Then practice counting from 1 to 10 several times.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read I Know Numbers! by Taro Gomi.
Meet Lala! She loves to read. She also loves looking for numbers and shapes in books. This book is an informational text because it teaches true facts.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read:

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: As you read the book, point out different ways numbers are used.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Here are two places we find numbers: a clock tells time. A calendar tells the date.
Our TVs and phones don’t look like this anymore! But we still use numbers to turn to a specific channel or to make a phone call.
Where have you seen numbers like this? They tell us how much money something costs. What kind of store do you think this is?
There are shoe and shirt sizes. What happens if the size is too small? Too big?
Where do you see numbers in this picture? We use numbers in addresses so we know where people live. 3615 is this girl’s house number.
These numbers tell us who is winning the game.
What does it look like the children are doing? They’re writing numbers and using counters. We’re going to do activities like this too!
Let’s talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to the guiding question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We can find numbers on a clock.
There are numbers on a phone.
We can find numbers at a soccer or baseball game.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about numbers as children watch.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can you find numbers in a store?
We can find numbers in a st____ . (store)
We can find numbers in a store.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Keeping a few mementos in the classroom can help children transition from home to preK. Familiar items, like family photos or a favorite book, can help make a new place seem less overwhelming. Reviewing the schedule every morning and posting a visual schedule will also help children feel more comfortable.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: ME and YOU | WEEK 1: All About Me

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Show Self-Awareness
section-block.rac_body-text: When you show self-awareness, you can describe who you are and what you’re good at. When you do something well, like help a friend or skip across the room, you feel proud.You can show your pride by smiling or even telling someone else about the thing you did that you are proud of.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread some pages of I Know Numbers! by Taro Gomi. We will use our show self-awareness Mind Builder to think about how this book is like our lives.
Clifford will also try to be self-aware and think about how he uses numbers in his life.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting and Measurement: As you read the book, point out different ways numbers are used.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We use calendars to keep track of special dates, like birthdays. Who knows their birthday? (MB)
What does temperature tell us? These are called thermometers. They measure temperature.

The numbers on buildings are called addresses. They tell us what street you live on, and which building is your house. Who knows their address? (MB) One way you show self-awareness is by being able to tell about yourself, like saying your address.
I see boys and girls running races and playing soccer. What sports have you played? Do you feel proud if your team wins?
Can you think of a time when you felt proud while playing sports? (MB)
Numbers are very useful. What are some ways you use numbers?

section.rac_body-text: Introduce children to the many manipulatives they will encounter during math time. Place one type of manipulative in each center or on tables around the room. Invite children to play with the manipulatives. Encourage them to visit as many centers as they can to get to know the different types of manipulatives.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about what numbers are used for.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Help children be aware by helping them get to know one another. Have children introduce themselves and say their name and age. Ask children to think of something else about them that is special and makes them feel proud, and have them share that as well. This will help children practice showing awareness and expressing pride in themselves in age-appropriate ways. (Bredekamp, 2009)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: ME and YOU | WEEK 1: All About Me

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children look through magazines, newspapers, or books to search for numbers. Ask children to show a partner the numbers they found.
Help children get their wiggles out by doing movements a specified number of times as you count aloud. For example, hop in place four times, or do six jumping jacks.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread I Know Numbers! by Taro Gomi.
Lala loves reading true books like this because she learns so much information.
Numbers tell us so much information. As we read today, think about this question:

section.rac_body-text: Facilitate back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is she standing on? This is a scale. The numbers on a scale tell you your weight.
These numbers are prices of different foods. What does a price tell you? How many price tags can you count?
These are road signs. Some of the signs tell how fast we can drive and some tell how far it is until a specific place.
If you count up the number of points that each team has, that number is called the score.
section.rac_body-text: Invite children to come to the book to count images on the pages.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How many players are sitting on the bench?
How many yellow hats do you see?
How many children are wearing pink shirts?
How many children do you count in this picture?
This number on the bottom of the page is called the page number. Page numbers count the number of pages that you’ve already seen in the book. What is this page number?
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? What are numbers used for?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to the question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Numbers tell us what page we’re reading.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about where we find numbers in our everyday lives.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do numbers show us a game’s score?
Numbers show us a game’s sc___ . (score)
Numbers show us a game’s score.
What do we use numbers for at school?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Multilingual learners may have different experiences with and use different vocabulary for some content depicted in the book. Spanish speakers might be confused with the false cognate for “plates” on page 12. On page 16, point out that the job title is a description of what that person does each day—he carries mail from house to house.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: ME and YOU | WEEK 1: All About Me

section-block.rac_body-text: Help children get to know their classmates better. Go around the circle and ask each child to say their name and one activity they like to do.
Ask children to act out an activity they like to do without using words. Challenge the other children to guess what activity the child is doing.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We will read this informational poster called I Like To.... It shows activities children like to do.
I Like To... and I Know Numbers! both show children doing different activities. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show I Know Numbers! book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s talk about the big ideas we’ve learned about this week:
What makes us who we are?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to All About Me
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: Read aloud the Teacher Text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask questions and to practice counting.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is your favorite book? What kinds of books do you like best? (MB)
We saw children playing sports in I Know Numbers! too. Have you ever played catch?
Have you ever touched a bunny? Does anyone here have a pet?
Drawing a square can be hard because we have to make all four sides the same exact length. What do you like to draw? (MB)
Do you like playing with blocks? What do you like to build with blocks?
What is your favorite food? How many children do you see eating pizza in this picture? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Give children paper and crayons, and ask them to draw pictures of activities they like to do. Encourage them to share the activities that make them who they are. If time permits, transcribe a sentence or two describing the picture.
Provide a writing prompt about using numbers. Give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Help children understand that many activities they enjoy are also good for their bodies. Active movement as well as mental stimulation promote good health. Extend the discussion to include other healthy choices such as eating healthily and getting enough sleep.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: ME and YOU | WEEK 1: All About Me

section-block.rac_body-text: Congratulate children on completing their first week of preK! Talk about what you are proud of children for accomplishing, and ask why they are proud of themselves.
Have children search the classroom for numbers. Encourage them to look in places you have talked about this week–on clocks, on calendars, in books, and elsewhere.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read I Know Numbers! one last time this week.
Lala wonders if this book tells a story or teaches information. Do you remember which kind of book this is?
We have learned about so many places where we can find and use numbers. When we read today, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is one way you use numbers every day?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and reenact the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the following activities.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s count to ten on our fingers. Hold your fingers up high!
Do you know anyone’s phone number? Let’s pretend to call someone.
Look inside your shoe! Do you see a number? That’s your shoe size!
Do you take the bus to go places? How do you know which bus is yours?
Is this bus taller or shorter than this car? Let’s pretend to drive a bus.
What sports do you like to watch? How do you know if your team is winning?
Let’s pretend that our team won the game with a score of five to one. How do you feel? (MB)
Do you have a favorite number? What is it? Why is it your favorite?

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is one way you use numbers every day?
section.rac_body-text: Give children time to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses to the guiding question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I call people on the phone.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a number story about themselves.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do you use numbers to say your shoe size?
I use numbers to say my shoe s___ . (size)
I use numbers to say my shoe size.
What is one new way you can use numbers that you learned this week?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Some children might already be able to count. Others might not yet know their numbers. Approach this skill with purpose, planning, and playfulness. Build on children’s current understanding and develop their readiness through fun activities.
